We present here the synthesis of three glucuronic acid configured carbocycles functionalized with azides in place of oxygen 4 or alkynes on the aziridine, with the eventual aim of growing selectivity for heparanase.


Abstract

Heparanase is an endo-acting β-glucuronidase responsible for the degradation of heparan sulfate structures in the extracellular matrix. The enzyme is found to be significantly upregulated in aggressive cancer types, aiding cell proliferation by liberation of growth factors, increasing angiogenesis and metastasis. Despite much interest in the development of inhibitors to control this activity, no compound targeting heparanase has yet been approved as a drug. While mechanism-based inhibitors derived from the natural product cyclophellitol are very potent enzyme inactivators through their reactive epoxide, one challenge in their development is in achieving selectivity for heparanase over related glycosidases while also maintaining a balance of appropriate pharmacological properties. item.dc:title: Alkyne‐ and Azide‐Functionalised Cyclophellitol Derivatives for Selective Glucuronidase Targeting

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Design, Synthesis and Characterization of BODIPY based 1H‐Tetrazole Ligands
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A novel fluorescence active ligand system consisting of a BODIPY derivative, linked to a 1H‐tetrazol‐1‐yl coordinating moiety via alkyl or benzyl spacers, is presented. The designed ligands exhibit remarkable emission properties even in solid state, which is complemented by crystal structure analysis. This enables future application of the ligands in various fields of coordination chemistry including spin‐crossover photoluminescence coupled systems.
Abstract Four novel fluorescence active ligands (1–4) consisting of a 1H‐tetrazol‐1‐yl moiety as coordinating unit and a 4,4‐difluoro‐4‐bora‐3a,4a‐diaza‐s‐indacene (BODIPY) derivative as fluorophore, bridged via alkyl (‐(CH2)n‐, n=1–3) or benzyl (‐CH2‐C6H4‐) spacers were designed. Successful synthesis is demonstrated by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy, as well as powder and single crystal XRD analysis. The methylene bridged ligand 2 (4,4‐difluoro‐1,3,5,7‐tetramethyl‐8‐[(1H‐tetrazol‐1‐yl)methyl]‐4‐bora‐3a,4a‐diaza‐s‐indacene) crystallizes in different polymorphs and solvatomorphs, in contrast to the other three ligands, which show no polymorphism under identical conditions. Photophysical studies revealed high fluorescence quantum yields (69 – 95 %) in solution for the ‐(CH2)2‐ bridged ligand 3 (4,4‐difluoro‐1,3,5,7‐tetramethyl‐8‐[(1H‐tetrazol‐1‐yl)ethyl]‐4‐bora‐3a,4a‐diaza‐s‐indacene) and the ‐(CH2)3‐ bridged ligand 4 (4,4‐difluoro‐1,3,5,7‐tetramethyl‐8‐[(1H‐tetrazol‐1‐yl)propyl]‐4‐bora‐3a,4a‐diaza‐s‐indacene). Non‐radiative decay due to rotational motion of the 1H‐tetrazol‐1‐yl‐ and/or ‐CH2‐C6H4‐ moiety for 2 and 1 (4,4‐difluoro‐1,3,5,7‐tetramethyl‐8‐[4‐((1H‐tetrazol‐1‐yl)methyl)phenyl]‐4‐bora‐3a,4a‐diaza‐s‐indacene) respectively leads to reduced quantum yields of ≥35 %. Complete fluorescence quenching upon aggregation is prevented by installation of the sterically demanding 1H‐tetrazol‐1‐yl moiety and a spacer in meso‐position of the BODIPY core to elongate the intermolecular distances between two adjacent BODIPY cores. Detailed photophysical and crystallographic investigations are supported by theoretical calculations.
item.content:encoded:
A novel fluorescence active ligand system consisting of a BODIPY derivative, linked to a 1H-tetrazol-1-yl coordinating moiety via alkyl or benzyl spacers, is presented. The designed ligands exhibit remarkable emission properties even in solid state, which is complemented by crystal structure analysis. This enables future application of the ligands in various fields of coordination chemistry including spin-crossover photoluminescence coupled systems.


Abstract

Four novel fluorescence active ligands (1–4) consisting of a 1H-tetrazol-1-yl moiety as coordinating unit and a 4,4-difluoro-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene (BODIPY) derivative as fluorophore, bridged via alkyl (-(CH2)n-, n=1–3) or benzyl (-CH2-C6H4-) spacers were designed. Successful synthesis is demonstrated by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy, as well as powder and single crystal XRD analysis. The methylene bridged ligand 2 (4,4-difluoro-1,3,5,7-tetramethyl-8-[(1H-tetrazol-1-yl)methyl]-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene) crystallizes in different polymorphs and solvatomorphs, in contrast to the other three ligands, which show no polymorphism under identical conditions. Photophysical studies revealed high fluorescence quantum yields (69 – 95 %) in solution for the -(CH2)2- bridged ligand 3 (4,4-difluoro-1,3,5,7-tetramethyl-8-[(1H-tetrazol-1-yl)ethyl]-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene) and the -(CH2)3- bridged ligand 4 (4,4-difluoro-1,3,5,7-tetramethyl-8-[(1H-tetrazol-1-yl)propyl]-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene). Non-radiative decay due to rotational motion of the 1H-tetrazol-1-yl- and/or -CH2-C6H4- moiety for 2 and 1 (4,4-difluoro-1,3,5,7-tetramethyl-8-[4-((1H-tetrazol-1-yl)methyl)phenyl]-4-bora-3a,4a-diaza-s-indacene) respectively leads to reduced quantum yields of ≥35 %. Complete fluorescence quenching upon aggregation is prevented by installation of the sterically demanding 1H-tetrazol-1-yl moiety and a spacer in meso-position of the BODIPY core to elongate the intermolecular distances between two adjacent BODIPY cores. Detailed photophysical and crystallographic investigations are supported by theoretical calculations.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: 1,4‐Dioxane as Precursor of −CH2CH2−: A Simple and Convenient Strategy to Synthesize 1,2‐Disulfide Substituted Ethanes Initiated by Iodine
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A novel precursor of −CH2CH2− has been achieved via the double C−O cleavage of 1,4‐dioxane under the proton acid condition of HI. Control experiments suggest that 1,2‐diiodoethane generated in‐situ is crucial for the formation of the product. This protocol for the construction of various 1,2‐disulfide substituted ethanes is very convenient and practical by its simple and mild conditions.
Abstract An unprecedented I2‐initiated nucleophilic ring opening reaction of 1,4‐dioxane with thiols for the construction of various 1,2‐disulfide substituted ethanes has been developed. Previously, dihalogenated ethane, acetylene or ethylene are often used as the pre‐cursor of −CH2CH2−. Through the cleavage of two C−O bonds, 1,4‐dioxane as precursor of −CH2CH2− has been achieved for the first time. In the presence of HI, thiols could be replaced by disulfides as nucleophile. This protocol is very convenient and practical by its simple and mild conditions.
item.content:encoded:
A novel precursor of −CH2CH2− has been achieved via the double C−O cleavage of 1,4-dioxane under the proton acid condition of HI. Control experiments suggest that 1,2-diiodoethane generated in-situ is crucial for the formation of the product. This protocol for the construction of various 1,2-disulfide substituted ethanes is very convenient and practical by its simple and mild conditions.


Abstract

An unprecedented I2-initiated nucleophilic ring opening reaction of 1,4-dioxane with thiols for the construction of various 1,2-disulfide substituted ethanes has been developed. Previously, dihalogenated ethane, acetylene or ethylene are often used as the pre-cursor of −CH2CH2−. Through the cleavage of two C−O bonds, 1,4-dioxane as precursor of −CH2CH2− has been achieved for the first time. In the presence of HI, thiols could be replaced by disulfides as nucleophile. This protocol is very convenient and practical by its simple and mild conditions.

item.dc:title: 1,4‐Dioxane as Precursor of −CH2CH2−: A Simple and Convenient Strategy to Synthesize 1,2‐Disulfide Substituted Ethanes Initiated by Iodine

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Application of Laser‐Generated Au‐Ag/Al2O3 Nanoparticle Catalysts for the Selective Catalytic Oxidation of 5‐(Hydroxymethyl) Furfural to 2,5‐Furan‐Dicarboxylic Acid
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
With reference to the sustainability and green synthesis towards biomass valorization, we report highly active and selective oxidation of the renewable feedstock HMF (78 % conversion) into the commercially important chemical FDCA (80 % selectivity) by implying specially designed and synthesized bimetallic AuAg nanoparticle catalysts supported on Al2O3 by laser ablation under mild basic conditions.
Abstract Conversion of lignocellulosic biomass‐derived 5‐(Hydroxymethyl) furfural (HMF) into 2,5‐Furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) has a high potential to replace petroleum‐based feedstocks for the production of plastics. In this study, a green synthesis strategy for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA is reported by using laser‐generated and specifically designed bimetallic AuAg nanoparticle catalysts supported on Al2O3 using molecular oxygen as oxidant and water as a solvent. Although supported AuAg catalysts are already known as suitable catalysts for this reaction, the optimal reaction conditions (type of base, reaction temperature, oxygen pressure), Au : Ag composition, role of metal‐support effects and origin of the active site still remain under debate. Interestingly, an Au9Ag1/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the highest activity with a FDCA yield of up to 66 % at 80 % HMF conversion. Hereby, NaHCO3 (instead of NaOH) as a smoother base in 2 : 1 base:HMF ratio, low oxygen pressures of 5 bar, and a mild temperature of 150 °C were found optimal. The yield remained fairly stable on reuse of the catalyst for 3 cycles without hints of catalyst sintering or leaching. The titration of surficial hydroxyls on the AuxAgy/Al2O3 surface showed the highest density of acidic hydroxyls for the most active Au9Ag1/Al2O3 catalyst. The respective hydroxyls potentially originate from metal‐support interactions between the AuAg nanoparticles with the alumina support and act as Lewis acidic sites that oxidize the alcohol moiety of HMF to form FDCA with high selectively. In summary, this study shows that the catalytic activity of AuAg catalysts in HMF oxidation is not just linked to an alloying effect but also to a metal‐support effect where the AuAg nanoparticles appear to directly affect the local acidity of the support.
item.content:encoded:
With reference to the sustainability and green synthesis towards biomass valorization, we report highly active and selective oxidation of the renewable feedstock HMF (78 % conversion) into the commercially important chemical FDCA (80 % selectivity) by implying specially designed and synthesized bimetallic AuAg nanoparticle catalysts supported on Al2O3 by laser ablation under mild basic conditions.


Abstract

Conversion of lignocellulosic biomass-derived 5-(Hydroxymethyl) furfural (HMF) into 2,5-Furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) has a high potential to replace petroleum-based feedstocks for the production of plastics. In this study, a green synthesis strategy for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA is reported by using laser-generated and specifically designed bimetallic AuAg nanoparticle catalysts supported on Al2O3 using molecular oxygen as oxidant and water as a solvent. Although supported AuAg catalysts are already known as suitable catalysts for this reaction, the optimal reaction conditions (type of base, reaction temperature, oxygen pressure), Au : Ag composition, role of metal-support effects and origin of the active site still remain under debate. Interestingly, an Au9Ag1/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the highest activity with a FDCA yield of up to 66 % at 80 % HMF conversion. Hereby, NaHCO3 (instead of NaOH) as a smoother base in 2 : 1 base:HMF ratio, low oxygen pressures of 5 bar, and a mild temperature of 150 °C were found optimal. The yield remained fairly stable on reuse of the catalyst for 3 cycles without hints of catalyst sintering or leaching. The titration of surficial hydroxyls on the AuxAgy/Al2O3 surface showed the highest density of acidic hydroxyls for the most active Au9Ag1/Al2O3 catalyst. The respective hydroxyls potentially originate from metal-support interactions between the AuAg nanoparticles with the alumina support and act as Lewis acidic sites that oxidize the alcohol moiety of HMF to form FDCA with high selectively. In summary, this study shows that the catalytic activity of AuAg catalysts in HMF oxidation is not just linked to an alloying effect but also to a metal-support effect where the AuAg nanoparticles appear to directly affect the local acidity of the support.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Photolabile ortho‐Nitro‐Benzyl Carbonate as an Amino Protecting Group for Stereocontrolled Synthesis of 2‐Amino‐2‐Deoxy‐β‐d‐Glycosides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The photolabile ortho‐nitrobenzyl carbonate (oNBC) was described as an amino protecting group for stereocontrolled synthesis of 2‐amino‐2‐deoxy‐β‐d‐glycosides. Under irradiation at 365 nm, deprotection of the multiple O‐ and N‐oNBC protecting groups of glycosides was effectively achieved with aminomethyl polystyrene (P‐CH2NH2) as the carbonyl scavenger.
Abstract Traditional amino protecting groups are often removed under harsh conditions or incompatible with other protecting groups, rendering the synthesis of complex 2‐amino‐2‐deoxy‐β‐d‐glycosides difficult. Here, we utilize the photolabile ortho‐nitrobenzyl carbonate (oNBC) as an amino protecting group for stereocontrolled synthesis of 2‐amino‐2‐deoxy‐β‐d‐glycosides. The gold(I)‐catalyzed glycosylation with per‐O‐oNBC‐protected 2‐N‐phthaloyl (Phth)‐2‐deoxy‐, 2‐N‐trichloroacetyl (TCA)‐2‐deoxy‐, and 2‐N‐oNBC‐2‐deoxy‐glycosyl ynenoates proceeded smoothly to provide 2‐amino‐2‐deoxy glycosides with exclusive β‐selectivities via the neighboring group participation (NGP) effect. Removal of the multiple O‐ and N‐oNBC protecting groups of 2‐amino‐2‐deoxy glycosides was achieved under irradiation at 365 nm with aminomethyl polystyrene as the carbonyl scavenger.
item.content:encoded:
The photolabile ortho-nitrobenzyl carbonate (oNBC) was described as an amino protecting group for stereocontrolled synthesis of 2-amino-2-deoxy-β-d-glycosides. Under irradiation at 365 nm, deprotection of the multiple O- and N-oNBC protecting groups of glycosides was effectively achieved with aminomethyl polystyrene (P-CH2NH2) as the carbonyl scavenger.


Abstract

Traditional amino protecting groups are often removed under harsh conditions or incompatible with other protecting groups, rendering the synthesis of complex 2-amino-2-deoxy-β-d-glycosides difficult. Here, we utilize the photolabile ortho-nitrobenzyl carbonate (oNBC) as an amino protecting group for stereocontrolled synthesis of 2-amino-2-deoxy-β-d-glycosides. The gold(I)-catalyzed glycosylation with per-O-oNBC-protected 2-N-phthaloyl (Phth)-2-deoxy-, 2-N-trichloroacetyl (TCA)-2-deoxy-, and 2-N-oNBC-2-deoxy-glycosyl ynenoates proceeded smoothly to provide 2-amino-2-deoxy glycosides with exclusive β-selectivities via the neighboring group participation (NGP) effect. Removal of the multiple O- and N-oNBC protecting groups of 2-amino-2-deoxy glycosides was achieved under irradiation at 365 nm with aminomethyl polystyrene as the carbonyl scavenger.

item.dc:title: Photolabile ortho‐Nitro‐Benzyl Carbonate as an Amino Protecting Group for Stereocontrolled Synthesis of 2‐Amino‐2‐Deoxy‐β‐d‐Glycosides

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Advances in the Direct N–C(sp2) Nitrone Synthesis from Oxime
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Nitrones are pivotal in organic chemistry, especially for the synthesis of natural and biologically active compounds via 1,3‐dipolar cycloadditions and Kinugasa reactions. Although numerous methods have been reported for the synthesis of nitrones with an sp3 carbon connected to a nitrogen atom, the development of nitrones with an sp2 carbon linkage, including N‐vinyl, N‐aryl, and N‐alkoxycarbonyl nitrones, remains relatively underexplored. This review summarizes the current research trends and methodologies for the direct synthesis of nitrones, in which an sp2 carbon is directly bonded to a nitrogen atom, beginning with oximes.
